thread.title: Sean Spicer Expects 'Greater Enforcement' Against Recreational Pot
thread.title_full: Sean Spicer Expects 'Greater Enforcement' Against Recreational Pot

author: Steven Nelson
title: Sean Spicer Expects 'Greater Enforcement' Against Recreational Pot
text:
Cancel White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer answers questions during the daily briefing at the White House. (Win McNamee/Getty Images) 
White House press secretary Sean Spicer indicated Thursday that state-legal medical marijuana programs are safe, but said he expects "greater enforcement" of federal law against state-legal recreational marijuana. 
The remarks at a press briefing come amid continued uncertainty about whether Attorney General Jeff Sessions will seek to use his office to crush state-regulated cannabis markets. 
Marijuana possession for any reason outside limited research remains a federal crime, but the Obama administration chose to allow broad state autonomy, permitting the emergence of a multibillion-dollar industry. 
More than half of states now allow medical marijuana, and eight states have laws authorizing recreational sales, though only four currently have operating markets. 
The Trump administration has provided little clarity on how its approach may differ from the Obama years, and some activists have taken to checking whether the Justice Department's 2013 Cole Memo allowing for recreational stores remains online. 
Bullish recreational shop owners and investors have said they believe the industry's size and popular support would protect them from Sessions, despite the former Republican senator's avowed opposition to legalization. 
But Spicer's Thursday comments may send a shiver down their spines. RELATED CONTENT
